1.77.text:
>> He is going to talk
about magic squares today.

7.94.text:
I appreciate this opportunity
to share my excitement

11.01.text:
about mathematics
with all of you.

14.38.text:
I ran across many squares for
the first time this summer,

17.48.text:
in a class entitled
"Math and the Arts."

21.12.text:
So, most people think,
"Math and art?

23.19.text:
"What in the world do those
have to do with each other?"

25.19.text:
So, I took a whole
class on the fact

26.73.text:
that they do have an awful lot
to do with each other, in fact.

29.33.text:
And we were represented
with this engraving.

32.63.text:
It's by a man named Durer-- I'm
probably butchering his name--

42.71.text:
And among many things, there's
some political statements

46.85.text:
there's some religious
statements going on here,

49.68.text:
but since this
is a math talk,

51.08.text:
we're going to talk about
the math going on here.

53.49.text:
If you notice up in this
upper right-hand corner,

56.49.text:
you can kind of make out
an outline of something.

59.09.text:
So, I zoomed
in on that.

61.29.text:
And you can see, of course,
the top of the angel's wings,

63.46.text:
and there's a bell and an
hourglass and a scale,

66.67.text:
which these things have quite
a bit to do with mathematics.

70.47.text:
But I'm most interested on this
engraving that's in the--

75.58.text:
this side of
the wall here.

76.98.text:
So, I'm going to
zoom in on that...

79.71.text:
and we can see this
array of numbers.

83.08.text:
And the first thing
that I notice

90.49.text:
And the second thing I notice
is that he created this in 1514

94.96.text:
and incorporated that
into his engraving.

99.43.text:
This thing is a little
difficult to read,

100.90.text:
so what I did was
I copied those numbers

103.47.text:
and put it like this,
so it's a little easier

109.68.text:
And then, the next thing
that's interesting is

112.11.text:
that each column--
in this case, row--

122.56.text:
and each main diagonal
adds up to 34.

128.39.text:
So, this thing is
called a "magic square,"

130.43.text:
and specifically, it's called
a "normal magic square."

134.83.text:
The size of the magic square
is the number of rows

137.37.text:
in the square-- and
since it's a square,

139.24.text:
also the number of columns
in the square.

141.64.text:
And we called this an
"n x n magic square,"

144.38.text:
and, in this case, it's
a 4 x 4 magic square.

148.01.text:
It's called "normal" if
it meets two conditions.

150.55.text:
The first condition is that
if you think of number 1

155.29.text:
as being the first number
in the 4 x 4--

168.74.text:
and each of the numbers is
being used-- whole numbers--

173.94.text:
The second condition is
that each row, each column,

178.55.text:
and the main diagonals
all add up to

182.98.text:
Sometimes, we call it
the "magic number,"

184.32.text:
and that's what I will
refer to it from now on,

187.99.text:
And in this case,
that magic number is 34.

195.63.text:
Sometimes, normal magic squares
is have additional magic,

201.17.text:
each of the corners
add up to 34...

204.67.text:
each of the corner
blocks add up to 34...

209.41.text:
and the middle block
adds up to 34.

212.68.text:
Durer did this in 1514,
and I can guarantee you

215.55.text:
he did it without
the use of a computer.

219.62.text:
So, let's create our
own magic square.

221.62.text:
We're talking about magic
squares-- let's make our own.

224.52.text:
This is a 1 x 1 magic square,
and its magic number is... 1.

231.86.text:
Great... well, that's
not very exciting.

234.67.text:
This is referred to as
the "trivial magic square,"

236.90.text:
which you can see
why it's trivial.

242.51.text:
So, I'm going to put all the
whole numbers from 1 to 4--

246.91.text:
and I notice right away
I have trouble,

255.25.text:
>> 4-- so, I somehow
have to get 4 and 7

258.96.text:
in some arrangement
to equal each other.

261.46.text:
And no matter how
I put this is,

263.20.text:
I'm still going to have
3 plus 4 equals 7,

269.64.text:
So, as it turns out, there's
no 2 x 2 magic square.

272.81.text:
Now, we're going to
move onto 3 x 3.

276.78.text:
Okay, so who can tell me how
many whole numbers we need

285.25.text:
So, we're going
to use that idea

292.09.text:
And we're going to
borrow somebody's idea--

295.90.text:
Now, Gauss died in 1855, so
this was quite a while ago.

301.30.text:
As the story goes, when
Gauss was in grade school,

304.37.text:
he was asked, along with
all his fellow students,

308.17.text:
to add up all the numbers
from 1 to 100--

312.51.text:
And as the story goes,
the professor--

314.21.text:
or the teacher, I suppose--
sat down at his desk,

317.45.text:
hoping to sort of relax for
the next, you know, half-hour

320.19.text:
or 45 minutes while all
the students added up,

323.89.text:
"okay, so then 3 plus 2,"
and on and on.

327.06.text:
Well, the story goes that,
almost immediately,

329.50.text:
Gauss went up with his
tablet-- his chalk tablet--

331.93.text:
and put it on the desk
with this number.

334.73.text:
And as it turns out,
that's correct.

336.77.text:
If I add up all the whole
numbers from 1 to 100,

340.91.text:
Well, the instructor
asked his student,

345.24.text:
"How in the world did you
come up with that so fast?"

347.08.text:
And it turns out, Gauss had
thought about this before.

350.15.text:
And he said, "Well,
here's the thing.

352.55.text:
"If I list all the numbers
out from 1 to 100--

360.26.text:
"and I do the same thing
in the other direction.

362.50.text:
"So, I go 1 plus 2 plus 3
plus 4 plus dot-dot-dot,

367.80.text:
"I noticed that all the
columns add up to 101."

372.97.text:
Pretty ingenious for
a grade schooler.

375.54.text:
"And of course, I
have 100 sets of 100.

382.92.text:
"divide it by 2, and
that turns out to be...

390.12.text:
And in general, if you
take the first number

397.80.text:
And in our case, he was
asked from 1 to 100.

400.70.text:
So, he said,
"m times m plus 1...

409.11.text:
So, in general, we can use this
idea that Gauss came up with

413.58.text:
from 1 to n^2--
in our case, 9--

419.19.text:
So, that's a 9 plus 9
plus 1, divided by 2.

425.12.text:
Well, because again, 9,
remember, is the same thing

437.77.text:
So, if we add up all of
these numbers, we have 45.

440.71.text:
But we want each
row and column--

442.88.text:
and there are
three of those--

444.78.text:
so we need to divide
that by a third--

446.95.text:
or multiply it
by a third...

451.42.text:
So, the magic number of
this 3 x 3 square is 15.

457.39.text:
As it turns out, we can
generalize this formula...

460.59.text:
because again, we're talking
about n^2 times n^2 plus 1,

464.50.text:
divided by 2,
multiplied by 1 over n.

467.70.text:
This n and one of
those n's simplify

472.44.text:
So, that's n times N^2
plus 1, divided by 2.

475.61.text:
This will tell us the magic
number of any magic square.

480.55.text:
And if we put these numbers in
directly, we get 3 times 10,

486.35.text:
So, we know our
magic number is 15.

488.99.text:
Next, we can do a little
careful deduction,

492.02.text:
to figure out what this
middle number has to be.

495.13.text:
I'm going to call it
"c" for a minute...

498.66.text:
and notice that I'm going to
have to use c plus two numbers

502.54.text:
to equal the magic
number that's 15.

507.57.text:
I use it here,
and here.

515.65.text:
c makes up
four of these.

518.22.text:
So, one of the c's
is in here,

519.95.text:
adding up the numbers
from 1 to 9.

521.89.text:
And then, I have
three others.

524.39.text:
Using Gauss's idea
again for 1 to 9--

530.43.text:
Simplifying this, this is
3c plus 45 is equal to 60.

541.41.text:
I divide both sides by 3,
and c is equal to 15--

546.28.text:
So, I know the middle number
of my 3 x 3 magic square

550.75.text:
Let's think about
one more clue.

553.39.text:
If I take the number 9, I have
to add it to two whole numbers

573.47.text:
I don't need to
go on because...

576.11.text:
9 plus 7 is more than 15, so
I'd have to go backwards.

580.05.text:
And as it turns out, I
can throw out this one

583.12.text:
because I would have
to use 3 twice,

584.68.text:
and the rule says
I only use it once...

587.52.text:
and I don't have a
zero anyways, right?

589.22.text:
So, I don't
need that one.

590.22.text:
I can take
those two out.

592.79.text:
And who can tell me the
property of addition

594.96.text:
that says this thing is
really the same thing as this?

602.17.text:
No one, in a room
full of math people?

608.21.text:
>> Commutative property--
how does that sound?

613.71.text:
is really the same thing
as 9 plus 2 plus 4.

616.22.text:
So, these four really are
just those two, right?

620.02.text:
So, what does
that tell me?

625.19.text:
So, if I put it in a corner,
I'm in trouble, right?

628.09.text:
Because it would have to get
used once, twice, three times.

632.26.text:
That means 9 cannot
be in a corner,

634.30.text:
and if it can
be in a corner

635.37.text:
and it can't be in the middle,
and because 5's already there,

637.47.text:
it has to be here or
here or here or there.

641.37.text:
So, 9 must be in
one of the middles.

643.81.text:
So, now, we have
these ideas.

644.88.text:
We have a middle,
which is 5,

646.45.text:
the whole thing
just add up to 15,

648.61.text:
and we know that the
corners can't be 9.

651.85.text:
So, let's take a few
minutes on your little...

655.72.text:
You can put in 5
in the middle...

658.16.text:
And see if we can come up
with our magic squares.

677.11.text:
Sometimes, trial and error
is the best way to do it.

697.20.text:
It's always fun having to do
addition on the spot, right?

699.33.text:
You have to really
think about...

707.91.text:
How are we doing?
Do we have one over here?

719.12.text:
Wait-- oh, you
want a new pencil?

720.99.text:
Oh, I can probably
handle that.

721.99.text:
Oh, you you've got it,
Mr. Dersch-- thanks.

730.43.text:
It looks really
good, I think.

735.47.text:
So, you folks can work on this
for the rest of the day...

743.84.text:
Wouldn't that be fun,
to work on magic squares

753.69.text:
All right, so,
as it turns out,

756.92.text:
we can find eight
possible solutions.

767.73.text:
are they really
eight different things?

771.67.text:
So, for example, I just happened
to choose this one first.

776.98.text:
8, 1, 6, 7, 2 always sort
of appear in that order

785.75.text:
And in every square, I see
the same-- 8, 1, 6, 7, 2.

794.53.text:
Or, for example, 4, 5, 6
always appear together.

811.21.text:
if I called-- I just
chose one of them--

814.68.text:
this one our initial
starting position--

820.39.text:
If I rotated it by 90 degrees,
this square becomes this square.

827.33.text:
So, notice 8 was in the
upper left-hand corner,

829.86.text:
I flipped it over one,
and now it's there.

834.17.text:
The same is true--
notice 5 doesn't change,

836.00.text:
it's always in the middle,
like a wheel spinning.

838.60.text:
If I did it twice, well,
then 8 moved from there,

843.98.text:
If I did it three times,
that'd be 270 degrees.

848.71.text:
And if I did it four times, I'd
be back to my initial square.

854.25.text:
This one is reflected
around the middle row.

857.89.text:
So, notice 3, 5, 7
is in the middle,

860.56.text:
but the 8 and the 4
flip places.

864.20.text:
Same thing with the 1
and the 9-- flip places.

867.83.text:
If we think about reflecting
around the middle column--

874.34.text:
but the 7 and the 3,
for example, just flip places.

878.08.text:
The same is true
for diagonal 1--

884.05.text:
and notice 8, 3, and 1
just flip places

888.09.text:
The same is true for
this one, going this way.

891.76.text:
Well, the 3 x 3, then, really
only has one solution, right?

896.60.text:
All the others are just
rotations and reflections

900.73.text:
And if we think of these other
rotations and reflections

902.97.text:
as a group of
things, then--

906.37.text:
mathematicians like to give
fancy names to things--

909.17.text:
this group of things
has a special name,

911.38.text:
and is called a "dihedral
group of degree 4."

916.72.text:
But all that really means
is that we call this group

920.75.text:
and there's this list of
eight things in this group.

926.59.text:
All right, this is the oldest
known example of a magic square.

931.30.text:
Chinese legend says the
emperor saw this magic square

934.83.text:
on the back of a
turtle in 2200 BC.

939.20.text:
Now, he didn't see
it with the numbers,

940.61.text:
because the Chinese didn't
have these numbers in 2200,

944.78.text:
but what he did see was a
rope with a series of knots.

949.08.text:
So, this is one knot,
this is five knots,

957.42.text:
Those of you who are
graph theorists,

961.33.text:
A lot of graph theory
going on there.

966.70.text:
This is probably the most
famous magic square--

972.37.text:
Okay, so now, I'll let
you in on a little secret.

976.14.text:
There is an algorithm
or a trick

978.38.text:
to constructing any
odd-numbered magic square,

982.11.text:
and that's what we're
going to do now.

984.22.text:
This is a 3 x 3,
which is odd.

986.42.text:
If I start in the middle
position with a 1,

991.56.text:
and I do what's called the
"up and over" method,

995.36.text:
and I go over one
and up one, this--

1001.07.text:
But if I think of the top and
the bottom of the magic square

1004.60.text:
wrapped around and touching
each other, like a donut--

1007.37.text:
like you'd wrap it
around a donut?

1009.98.text:
Then, this 2, really,
I can put down here.

1015.31.text:
The same idea-- if I go
over and up, this 3--

1019.12.text:
there's no square there,
but if I think of the sides

1021.19.text:
of the magic square
being wrapped around

1022.72.text:
and touching each other, then
this is really this square.

1028.29.text:
So, I can put
that there.

1030.70.text:
And then, finally,
if I go over and up

1034.87.text:
then I drop it
down to here.

1038.00.text:
So, the next goes
over and up to 5.

1043.71.text:
The next goes over
and up to 6.

1047.58.text:
The next goes over and up-- but
again, if I think of the sides

1051.18.text:
as being rotated around
and touching each other,

1053.59.text:
and stretched around the top
to be touching each other,

1060.03.text:
which is occupied, so
we drop it down one.

1062.46.text:
Same idea-- over and
up, it's this one...

1065.56.text:
and over and up is
really that one.

1068.00.text:
>> Can you please explain
how to get from 3 to 4?

1071.74.text:
>> Oh, the drop-- so let
me back up here a second.

1074.77.text:
This is the hardest
part, right?

1077.78.text:
If I go over and up and
it's already occupied,

1080.45.text:
then drop it
down one below.

1082.01.text:
>> Oh, it just
goes straight down?

1085.08.text:
So, over and up is 5,
it's not occupied,

1086.75.text:
over and up is
not occupied.

1088.62.text:
But now, when I go over
and up, it's occupied,

1091.09.text:
so I drop
it down one.

1092.29.text:
Yes, sir?
>> How did you know

1093.63.text:
to start with 1 in the
middle, in the center?

1098.73.text:
Yeah, you have to start
with the 1 in the middle,

1102.80.text:
>> You could be on any of
the edges in the center.

1105.44.text:
>> Yes-- as long as you think of
it-- if you start here, and--

1108.41.text:
>> You could start there and--
>> Yeah, yeah.

1110.44.text:
But you have to be careful
because then you have to think

1112.24.text:
of it as a reflection, so you
have to be a little careful.

1118.25.text:
I always start with
it on the top,

1119.45.text:
'cause it's easier to sort of
keep track of what's going on.

1122.35.text:
(chuckling)
So, this makes, in this case,

1127.86.text:
So, let's do it for
the 5 x 5, all right?

1130.90.text:
So we're going to start
with the 1 in the middle,

1133.67.text:
and we go over one
and up one...

1135.53.text:
and again, the top
is wrapped around,

1138.07.text:
so that's really
this one down here.

1141.54.text:
I go over and
up one for 3.

1144.54.text:
Over and up one-- the
sides are wrapped around,

1152.95.text:
I go over and up one
that's occupied already,

1155.99.text:
so I drop down
to below.

1166.00.text:
Over and up is
now down here.

1172.80.text:
Over and up is
really over here.

1176.28.text:
Over and up is occupied,
so that's 11.

1188.12.text:
Now, we have a column, so let's
check to see how we're doing.

1192.46.text:
So, remember the general formula
for the magic square--

1195.06.text:
is for the magic number
is n times n^2 plus 1,

1205.30.text:
so that's 5 times 5^2 plus 1,
divided by 2.

1211.78.text:
So, this is 5 times 26,
divided by 2.

1215.88.text:
I'm going to cancel out the 26
and the 2 to make 13,

1224.46.text:
and 5 times 3 is 15,
so that equals 65.

1229.33.text:
How does that look, Mr. Lee?
>> Oh, fine.

1235.53.text:
so now I'm gonna do a
little Chicago math here.

1245.28.text:
And 2 and 1 makes...
uh, I dunno.

1249.15.text:
And then, I add 3
and I add 65, right?

1251.45.text:
That's my joke about
Chicago math, by the way.

1254.69.text:
So, this diagonal
adds up to 65.

1260.16.text:
So, we're gonna go
over one and up one,

1262.59.text:
and that's occupied,
so we drop down to 16.

1266.03.text:
We go over one
and up one,

1268.07.text:
and then again, it wraps
around and it goes to 17.

1272.70.text:
Over one and up one
is now 18.

1276.21.text:
Same thing-- over one
and up one for 19.

1279.28.text:
Over one and
up one is 20.

1282.01.text:
Over one and up one is
occupied, so we drop down,

1285.68.text:
and we have a row-- let's
check to make sure it's 65.

1302.07.text:
Over and one is this
one over here, is 23...

1311.28.text:
So, that takes a little
practice, right?

1314.61.text:
But it works for any
odd-numbered magic square.

1320.45.text:
By the way, you can
impress your friends--

1323.36.text:
if you do this with a 3 x 3,
you can start with any number.

1328.99.text:
So, you say to
your friends,

1337.30.text:
and use the same for 27, 28, 29,
till the magic square is filled,

1340.94.text:
and you'll have
a magic square.

1342.61.text:
It's not really a normal
magic square, right,

1346.45.text:
but it's still kind of fun
to impress your friends,

1349.38.text:
and if you really do a lot
of mental arithmetic,

1351.95.text:
ask them to give you a
number from 1 to 100,

1353.72.text:
they'll give you a number, and
then you can work backwards,

1357.62.text:
right, so that your magic square
equals the number they gave you.

1362.03.text:
All right, is everybody
following what I'm saying?

1363.83.text:
Well, that takes a
little practice...

1366.03.text:
and you can look it up
online for some practice.

1369.90.text:
Okay, so the question now
is, we saw in the 3 x 3

1373.37.text:
that the magic square
was unique for a 3 x 3,

1376.71.text:
so is this 5 x 5
magic square unique?

1387.89.text:
and notice 11 doesn't have
12 around it anywhere--

1398.20.text:
So, if it's not
unique-- oh, I'm sorry.

1403.14.text:
Uh, there are some
similarities, though.

1405.37.text:
Each corner with the middle
adds up to the magic number.

1409.47.text:
This pattern on both adds
up to the magic number.

1413.81.text:
But how many unique 5 x 5
magic squares are there?

1422.99.text:
What do you think-- do you
think it's more than seven?

1428.59.text:
Well, as it turns out,
it's that many.

1432.90.text:
>> All right, so
let me think here.

1442.77.text:
This was discovered by
Richard Schroeppel at MIT

1447.35.text:
This is when computers
were, you know--

1450.88.text:
As it turns out, Mr. Schroeppel
and his friends

1455.42.text:
that was sponsored by the
US Department of Defense--

1457.56.text:
it still is-- studying
artificial intelligence.

1462.09.text:
Because if I
write a program

1464.83.text:
and I claim it's
artificially intelligent,

1466.43.text:
how do you test if it's
really intelligent?

1469.33.text:
Well, one way we can do
that is say, "The computer

1472.44.text:
certainly knows how to add--
I've told it how to do that.

1477.11.text:
"and it certainly knows
what whole numbers are."

1479.54.text:
And I say, "Computer,

that's a possibility.

2946.14.text:
Because again, like you said,
there is this symmetry

2949.38.text:
that is true with
the integers,

2951.25.text:
and it may well
have been that way,

2954.52.text:
that when he was
finished, he went--

2955.75.text:
>> I picture trying to
force all these directions--

2959.26.text:
>> To happen, yeah.
>> --out of sheer will.

2962.09.text:
I don't care how much time
and energy or how smart you are.

2970.30.text:
>> To get it to work, right?
(laughing)

2972.74.text:
And imagine what happens when
you had all the way down to here

2974.40.text:
and you're like,
"No, it doesn't work!"

2978.01.text:
So no, I believe there is
a symmetry in mathematics.

2983.48.text:
So maybe it happened as an
effect of getting it to work

2989.72.text:
You'd be really
interesting to think about.

2992.12.text:
And you know, many of
us in this room know

2996.29.text:
there is a lot of heavy
mathematics going on here,

2999.46.text:
and it's not more than just
adding some numbers together.

3001.90.text:
So, I haven't gotten
to that point yet

3005.17.text:
where I understand all
these heavy mathematics,

3015.21.text:
>> Okay, so that's an
interesting question.

3018.62.text:
If you're talking about
that a person has made,

3021.12.text:
that's different than they've
made a computer made, right?

3024.09.text:
So you can go to websites--
there's online periodicals,

3029.83.text:
where people publish
their magic squares.

3034.20.text:
And the biggest I have
seen is a 24 x 24

3036.77.text:
that a person
actually worked out.

3040.67.text:
you know, a computer can
do whatever it wants.

3043.44.text:
It's just the amount
of time it takes.

3045.04.text:
So, the biggest I've
seen is a 24 x 24.

3048.61.text:
But you can-- you have time
over Christmas break, right?

3051.35.text:
See what size
you can make.

3056.15.text:
Well, if you had a
room like this, you can
get a big chalkboard

3059.62.text:
Yes, sir?
>> Have you ever counted through

3062.06.text:
1 through 64 on this and
recognized any patterns here?

3068.20.text:
>> If you look down
there, you start at one.

3070.07.text:

and up one, 2,

3074.34.text:
over and up one to 4--
>> Uh-huh.

3077.91.text:
Start with 5-- oh,
5 and 6 are backwards but--

3083.71.text:
>> Then 9 to 10-- it's
a little hard to see,

3089.62.text:
but it does
follow a pattern.

3091.99.text:
I was just
wondering if that--

3093.56.text:
>> And it very well
possibly could be.

3098.73.text:
mathematics is deeply
symmetric and if--

3102.93.text:
I'm confident if it was

3106.37.text:
And especially when you're
talking about-- oh, sorry.

3111.74.text:
>> My man was
catchin' a pattern!

3114.51.text:
Wait, it will go
through one more time.

3117.15.text:
I don't know how to stop the

3123.52.text:

3124.55.text:
does anyone else

3128.53.text:
And what makes it cool to me

3135.80.text:
and so-- I mean, people

3139.87.text:

3142.57.text:
where there are some other

3144.84.text:
that don't reach across that

3164.79.text:
